Title: Alive
Author: Chandler Baker
Notes: From the summary, it seems to be some sort of cross between The Fault in Our Stars and Twilight--basically, some girl has her life changed by some boy, also there's some concept of illness and paranormal activity. Not really my cup of tea.

Title: All the Bright Places
Author: Jennifer Niven
Notes: Compelled by my research on these books, I decided this book is on my to-read list. It's another book about mental illness, a category which I started liking in 2009.

Title: The Game of Love and Death
Author: Martha Brockenbrough
Notes: It's a Depression-era historical fiction book about star-crossed lovers. I think I would like it, save for all the romantic parts.

Title: Six of Crows
Author: Leigh Bardugo
Notes: This is the first book in a fantasy-adventure series. I immediately stopped reading the description after I read "Break into the notorious Ice Court". I have a hard time being invested in high fantasy books.

Title: Everything, Everything
Author: Nicola Yoon
Notes: This is like The Fault in Our Stars, except that I haven't read it. They made it into a movie, though.

Title: Every Last Word
Author: Tamara Ireland Stone
Notes: The premise of this book is compelling, since dealing with mental illness is a topic that is becoming more popular in YA recently, but this one centers around a character with OCD rather than depression. I added this to my to-read list, even though I wasn't aware of this book until I started this project.

Title: The Novice
Author: Taran Matharu
Notes: With fantasy adventure books, it's hard enough for me to read the summary, let alone the whole book. Here's a sample of the description: "Fletcher is put through grueling training as a battlemage to fight in the Hominum Empire’s war against orcs."  That means nothing to me.

Title: Illuminae
Author: Arnie Kaufman, Jay Kristoff
Notes: An entire, potentially compelling, dystopian world is constructed for a series about a girl having to work with her ex-boyfriend.  I hope reading this description was as disappointing for you as reading the summary was for me.

Title: When
Author: Victoria Laurie
Notes: A fun mystery book about a girl who sees others' death dates. Not that I've read it, but I might now that I've learned about it.

Title: Suicide Notes from Beautiful Girls
Author: Lynn Weingarten
Notes: First sentence in the description: "Pitched as Gone Girl meets Thirteen Reasons Why." Seems to me to be using suicide as a ploy for some non-mental health related mystery, but what do I know, I haven't read this.

Title: The Shadow Throne
Author: Jennifer A. Nielsen
Notes: The third book in a trilogy I've never heard of, The Shadow Throne is considered a YA/children's fantasy book. I don't really have anything to add to that except that I have no plans to read it.

Title: I Become Shadow
Author: Joe Shine
Notes: Ah, a convoluted sci-fi/spy adventure book. I hope the worldbuilding supports the complexity of the summary provided on Goodreads.

Title: To All the Boys I've Loved Before
Author: Jenny Han
Notes: The title almost sounds compelling, as if perhaps it's about some sort of mystery. Alas, it's just another romance, so I don't read a bit.

Title: My Life with the Walter Boys
Author: Ali Novak
Notes: "Now Jackie must trade in her Type A personality and New York City apartment for a Colorado ranch and all the wild Walter boys who come with it." I, myself, had to move from New York to North Carolina...and yet, I have no sympathy for this main character and this book seems like another predictable YA romance.

Title: Heir of Fire
Author: Sarah J. Maas
Notes: Apparently, this is a sequel to another fantasy book I definitely didn't read.

Title: The Bane Chronicles
Author: Cassandra Clare, Sarah Rees Brennand, and Maureen Johnson
Notes: This is a collection of fantasy short stories by three authorsabout the same guy. As a concept for novel creation, it sounds interesting. As a narrative, not so much.

Title: The Young Elites
Author: Marie Lu
Notes: A cross between sci-fi/dystopian and fantasy, this book has a pretentious name for a potentially gritty story. That said, as a post-Hunger Games dystopian book, the arc of the series seems predictable.

Title: The Kiss of Deception
Author: Mary E. Pearson
Notes: I think the only category I like less than fantasy or romance is fantasy and romance about a princess.

Title: Since You've Been Gone
Author: Morgan Matson
Notes: It's like Paper Towns, in that I haven't read it, and is unlike Paper Towns, in that I don't plan on reading it.  But it is another book where a Manic Pixie Dream Girl disappears, leaving the main character to do their own shenanigans.

Title: The Geography of You and Me
Author: Jennifer E. Smith
Notes: The title reminded me of the maps from Ned Vizzini's "It's Kind of a Funny Story", except this book is just romantic fiction and therefore has nothing I find interesting, which is quite the opposite of Vizzini's novel.

Title: Eleanor & Park
Author: Rainbow Rowell
Notes: I heard all the hype about this book, and I quite liked the cover art. The problem is, I find romantic fiction largely uninteresting, so I never did anything besides briefly admire the cover art before browsing other books.

Title: Divergent
Author: Veronica Roth
Notes: Because of Matched, I grew wary of YA dystopian novels, and never even read it, even though I did find the summary somewhat interesting.

Title: The Fault in Our Stars
Author: John Green
Notes: I read this once the movie was going to come out, since, just as with Twilight, I was invited to see the movie with friends. I actually did not end up seeing the movie with them, and honestly I wasn't as moved by the book as many others. It was still good though--I mostly read it because I like John Green as a person.

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children
Author: Ransom Riggs
Notes: Upon its release, I didn not realize it was a YA book, so I never looked at it. I did see the movie when it came out, though, and I would have liked it.

Title: Where She Went
Author: Gayle Forman
Notes: Personally, I didn't understand why the follow up to If I Stay was so popular, since I didn't think the original book was compelling enough by itself.

Title: Clockwork Angel
Author: Cassandra Clare
Notes: What a surprise, another YA dystopian book in the post-Hunger Games world.

Title: Mockingjay
Author: Suzanne Collins
Notes: The end of the Hunger Games series was a little less than satisfying, but it was relieving. That was the last series that I ever read where I had to wait for the next book to be written.  Awaiting the continuation of narrative is a pain I appreciate largely from a nostalgic lens.

Title: Matched
Author: Ally Condie
Notes: Ugh. This book is the one that made me realize that the sudden proliferation in dystopian literature caused a sharp decrease in actual narrative quality. As a person, I'm generally opposed to not finishing books, and I did finish Matched, albeit with a few qualms. I bought the second and third books, but by halfway through the second, I realized that it was all pointless, the worldbuilding was mediocre, and I could probably guess the plot for the rest of the series.

Title: Before I Fall
Author: Lauren Oliver
Notes: Sometimes I would conflate this book and "If I Stay", probably because they're both about post-car-crash life-or-death scenarios. I had previously found Lauren Oliver books to be hit-or-miss, so I decided to pass on this one. However, they made it into a movie this year, which I don't intend to watch. A book of Lauren Oliver's I did like was Delirium, since it had an interesting premise for a dystopia. However, its execution was mediocre and I never finished that series.

Title: Catching Fire
Author: Suzanne Collins
Notes: The release of the second book in the Hunger Games series sparked the sale of various book-related merchandise. I bought two Hunger Games tees, both of which I still own. (It's not so much that I liked it two whole shirts worth, but they were having a sale as well.)

Title: City of Glass
Author: Cassandra Clare
Notes: I really didn't realize that each book in this series was highly acclaimed.  Other dystopian series usually had their sequels fall off the top 10 unless the series was actually very compelling. See: City of Bones.

Title: Along for the Ride
Author: Sarah Dessen
Notes: Apparently, Sarah Dessen didn't live far from my high school, so after this book came out she visited my high school. A friend wanted me to go to get a book signed for her. I can't even remember if I did it or not, because I still found Sarah Dessen's stereotypically girly novels offensive to my taste.

Title: If I Stay
Author: Gayle Forman
Notes: I read part of this book in 2014 while sitting in the back of a Barnes and Noble. I probably read a chapter or two. I found it pretentious and shallow. They made a movie out of it despite my objections, and I haven't seen it, but I might just to skip to the ending.

Title: Wintergirls
Author: Laurie Halse Anderson
Notes: This is one of the few contemporary YA books I ever liked--perhaps because it wasn't a romance, for once. Instead it was about two girls dealing with eating disorders, which I found poignant.

Title: Paper Towns
Author: John Green
Notes: This John Green book came out before I knew who John Green was. It's on my list of books to read now, though, especially because it became a movie, and I don't like to watch the movie before reading the book.

Title: Breaking Dawn
Author: Stephenie Meyer
Notes: I was so glad to finish the Twilight series, just because I needed a resolution to whatever happened in Eclipse, and because it let me join in on both thoughts and critiques about the series.

Title: The Hunger Games
Author: Suzanne Collins
Notes: While for most of 8th grade I refused to read this book because it had become popular, one of my friends in Latin class told me a bit about the plot and I figured I would give it a shot. I really liked it, and was glad that it sparked more dystopian novels for my age group--until I realized that none of them really measured up to this world and narrative.

Title: City of Ashes
Author: Cassandra Clare
Notes: It occurs to me that I might even like this book, but I've never read the summary. See: City of Bones.

Title: The Disreputable History of Frankie Landau-Banks
Author: E. Lockheart

Title: Eclipse
Author: Stephenie Meyer
Notes: I literally don't know what happens in this book. I read the entire Twilight series, and even half of one of the auxiliary books, but I honestly do not know what happens in this novel. I think the true testament to how important this book was to me is exemplified by the fact that I really don't even care to look up the summary.

Title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
Author: J.K. Rowling
Notes: It was really hard to accept the end of this era. It was the end of my childhood, it felt, since I had been reading the books since I was six years old. It was also the end of my time living in New York, as around the time this book was released, I learned that we would be moving.

Title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid
Author: Jeff Kinney
Notes: I really failed to comprehend the popularity of this book. It started off seeming to have a negative premise with a 4th-grade-like cover, which struck me as too childish for me, a thirteen year old.

Title: Vampire Academy
Author: Richelle Mead
Notes: One of the many post-Twilight vampire fiction series. I am just as confused now as I was then about the sudden spike in interest in vampires, because Twilight wasn't exactly the most revolutionary book.

Title: Maximum Ride: Saving the World and Other Extreme Sports
Author: James Patterson

Title: City of Bones
Author: Cassandra Clare
Notes: I never read this series, and by the time I noticed its existence, it was caught up in the flurry of post-Hunger Games dystopian series which, on average, all seemed to me to have the same plot and cover art.

Title: Extras
Author: Scott Westerfeld
Notes: Westerfeld's surprise 4th novel to the Uglies series was amazing. I loved the world he built and I was very happy to see what he thought the effects of dismantling the original dystopian system would be. However, since I was such an invested fan, I did probably have some qualms about some details.

Title: Before I Die
Author: Jenny Downham
Notes: I didn't read this book because I wasn't really interested in contemporary fiction, and especially not predictable dramas.

Title: Twisted
Author: Laurie Halse Anderson
Notes: I actually read this in 2015, and was disappointed because this author also wrote Wintergirls (2010), which I thought was a compelling book. However, when a friend recently saw this book on my shelf, they asked me about it, and even just by reading the synopsis aloud I ended up yelling "This book has no plot!" Therefore, I won't bore you with it.

Title: New Moon
Author: Stephenie Meyer
Notes: This book is unbearable to read. On one hand, I respect that the effect on the reader mirrors that of the main character. Still, the character was flat and it was another book in the Twilight series.

Title: Just Listen
Author: Sarah Dessen
Notes: Sarah Dessen's books seemed to have very gendered marketing, which I found deeply annoying. I didn't even want anyone to catch me looking at those books for fear I might appear like a stereotypical girl.

Title: How to Ruin a Summer Vacation
Author: Simone Elkeles
Notes: I was unaware of the existence of this book, which is fine, because I don't feel like I missed anything.

Title: Firegirl
Author: Tony Abbott
Notes: In this book, which turns out to not be the sequel to Stargirl, the main character is a boy and the person of interest is a girl who sticks out from everyone else. So it still seems like the sequel to Stargirl, a novel I had to read for 6th grade literature.

Title: All Hallows Eve
Author: Vivian Vande Velde
Notes: My mother didn't let me read or watch anything spooky, because she did that as a child and gave herself nightmares.

Title: Life As We Knew It
Author: Susan Beth Pfeffer
Notes: This wasn't my first dystopian series--Uglies was the first one I read. But this is one of the few YA dystopian series that I thought was actually well-conceived and well-written, perhaps because it was before Hunger Games made dystopian YA literature popular.

Title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
Author: J.K. Rowling
Notes: Every time a Harry Potter book was released after 2001, my parents took my brother and me to the release party at the nearby Borders bookstore. (Little did I know Borders would not exist by 2011.)  He and I had capes and light-up wizard wands and all other sorts of things.

Title: Twilight
Author: Stephenie Meyer
Notes: At first I didn't read it because of all the hype. But I was in 8th grade, so once I was invited to see the movie with friends, I couldn't pass up the opportunity to be included. By high school, the cool thing was to talk about how bad of a book Twilight is and how flawed the plot, writing, and characters are. At the same time, I also read all four books and saw the first two movies, while hating the onslaught of vampire fantasy novels that followed this book.

Title: Eldest
Author: Christopher Paolini
Notes: This is the third book in the Eragon series. I did not read this series. As a child, I considered myself very anti-fantasy. However, I also was a massive Harry Potter fan since I started reading it in 1st grade (2001). But when I saw that Eragon was popular, I decided not to read it, because I was a quite contrary child.

Title: Peeps
Author: Scott Westerfeld
Notes: Written by Scott Westerfeld, this book is about something, probably. I loved Scott Westerfeld's Uglies series. He and Margaret Peterson Haddix were my favorite authors at the time because they wrote great Sci-Fi/Dystopian books that a 10-year-old could read. On the other hand, I loved the Uglies series so much that I feared not liking anything else Westerfeld wrote, especially since samples of this book were printed in the back of some of my Uglies books.

Title: 13 Little Blue Envelopes
Author: Maureen Johnson
Notes: This book seemed to be presented in this aggressively "girly" context, and, since I always hated following imposed gender roles, I never touched this book. However, as a current fan of John Green, knowing that Maureen Johnson is his friend does make me consider revising my decision.

Title: Captain Hook: The Adventures of a Notorious Youth
Author: J.V. Hart
Notes: I was pretty proud of not having seen most Disney movies, and so even though I knew who Captain Hook was, I had no incentive to remember, let alone consider, this book.

Title: If I Have a Wicked Stepmother, Where's My Prince?
Author: Melissa Kantor

Title: Elsewhere
Author: Gabrielle Zevin
Notes: Somehow, the summary already makes me think the main character is just being whiny, for which I have no sympathy. Even if she's being whiny because she died as a teenager.
